commentBody: Well, that was different.

Did you guys publish a Tuesday instead by ACCIDENT? This was way too easy IMO. Gold star in under 15 minutes which is a RARE EVENT for me on Thursdays. 

TOO MUCH?
No rebuses. You can come out now.
As someone whose sentences have been accused of being overqualified, I greatly enjoyed the theme’s wordplay, literally. Thanks Adam!

Loved this puzzle. Forgetting about the theme,  it solved like a chewy themeless, with a lot of misdirects for me—ADAM before SELF, UCSD before SDSU, LINENS before DIAPER, I could go on—and good fill and clever clues. As for the theme, it’s getting scary—I saw the first one “meditation chant, in a sense” and I immediately knew this would be OM inside a sense word. But even understanding the theme, there were no gimmes with it, even with RAREEVENT because I thought it was Christopher REEVES. The theme helped but didn’t give anything away, the best of both worlds. Big thumbs up.

The theme clues were very clever, but ultimately of no practical use. All the theme answers were easily gotten via crosses, whereupon the clues became nothing more than a double check. Still, it was a nice crunchy workout.
Easy-ish but fun Thursday. Had BAR for 'goal to shoot for' which slowed me down a bit.

I thought that was a lot of fun.

It was even more fun once I dumped SalesAD in favor of STOREAD.  That made a lot of troublesome crosses quite friendly.

Good puzzle for my money.

Yeah, imma say it.  I’m just not smart enough for Thursday through Saturday. 

Good work on a clever puzzle.

“Touch” is a sense.
“Route” is a way.
“Rant” is so many words.
“Accent” is a manner of speaking.
“Pecan” is a nutshell?

Actually, I mostly wasted time with BAR instead of PAR, wondering if a PRIZEBOT was some kind of online gambling feature.

HINNY

today I learned that a mule with a donkey mom is not a mule at all. It's a "hinny", which, despite being an animal person, is a term I've never heard until today. 

When you mix a lion and a tiger you get a liger or a tigon. But mix a horse and a donkey, you don't get a horkey or a donse. Nope, a mule or a hinny. 

I really wish there were horkeys.

Creative theme. The themers were actual words. 
Fun solve. 

I would really really really like a YouTube video on what the heck you are talking about in the constructor notes. I think it would be very interesting for the solving masses, like me. 

Get on it Adam.

I’m an insomniac and I’m first!!!???
Om inside touch.
Reeve inside rant.
ID inside accent.
Let inside route.
Li inside a pecan.
A Thursday rip snorter, by gum.
Seriously…I just can’t sleep.

Dang...I'm not first...
But everybody knows that nouns in English don't have genders. So I'm confused by 4 Down.

Had kiNG before HONG, though OPTICAL led me to delete; adam before SELF, which I held on to for way too long given IFNOT felt obvious; and zorse before HINNY, though I have heard of the latter. (I can never remember which way around the parenting goes though.)

Fun fact: with both mules and hinnies, the front half looks like dad and the back half like mom. 

Also, obligatory PELICAN poem:

A wondrous bird is the pelican:
His beak can hold more than his belican.
He holds in his beak
Enough food for a week.
But I'm darned if I know how the helican.

I could not get hinny. The down needed the vowel in cuz.. I couldn't get the u there as I thought cuz was short for cousin not 'cause. So I missed the two letters there. Otherwise I sort of got the theme

Fun puzzle! 

Although it is worth noting that 'One' in German is actually 'Eins'. It's used without the 's' as a quantifier for a noun, but the number on its own is written differently.
Nah
Cheeky Adam, to make us *think* he had inserted himself in the puzzle.
I'm so upset that 16A wasn't  "hated it" 😅

Fun solve. I picked up on the trick with TO(OM)UCH and was off to the races from there. But I didn’t fully appreciate the ingenuity of the theme until after I finished. 

First, the constructor came up with five different phrases that mean the same thing (“in a sense”, “in a way”, “in so many words”, “in a manner of speaking”, “n a nutshell”). 

Then, he came up with of one word to cleverly represent each phrase (touch, route, rant, accent, pecan). 

THEN, the pièce de résistance. Finding a word that can be embedded within each word that makes a completely new word. Amazing! 

PE(LI)CAN is my favorite. 

Congratulations, Adam. Excellent work!

Hinny?  ~HINNY~ ????

Gimme a break.

Solved the puzzle okay without understanding the themers, just ignored the clues got them from crosses.

Got here and read the explanation and I am even more glad I didn't waste any time on them.

Wow, that was hard for a Thursday, and I really enjoyed it!  The theme itself was tough to get for a while, and it proved to be interesting and fun too.  More crucially the theme actively helped me complete the puzzle.  I just love when it's more than tangential windows dressing.  If you catch this one it opens up a lot.

This was mildly terrifying for me for a bit, much more so than the average Thursday.  Well done!  And it took me a while to change first person from "Adam", you sly dog you.

I tried but I just couldn't deal with the fill without lookups - I googled SHOFARS (seen the word here before but it didn't stick), OTHELLO (never heard of it, I think, and I definitely never played it), GIDEON (a complete mystery to me), SDSU (well, duh), and LACERTA (apparently the Polish name is Jaszczurka, which means lizzard. All constellations have Polish names in Polish. I've never heard of it even though apparently it's visible from here and we learned about the night sky in school).

Then I had to rely on crosses for other clues or entries I did not understand. For example, I know nothing about sport betting in Polish or English, as I abhor gambling, so I only got OVERUNDER with almaot all the letters already there. Ditto BERATED, as I didn't know what "Chewed out" might mean.

As for the theme, I got it in the end. Unluckily, the first themed entry I got from crossew was the one in the SE (easiest corner for me, filled very quickly), PELICAN. Its clue looked like a word salad to me. It's not explained in the column, either (my stumpers rarely are...), and google is no help - it inanely insists on telling me about Jet Li when I try to find a connection between Jets (a sport team?) and Li (a player?)

I finally understood the theme upon analyzing ACC-ID-ENT. After that Aha! moment I was able to complete the puzzle. That was quite a good theme.

I sort of liked the puzzle I guess, but I wish the fill were less arcane.

TRANSAM made me smile.  I remember some of the rich kids who drove Transams to high school.  They were beautiful.  6.6L it said on the hood.  Sitting next to CJ5’s with lift kits, giant mud tires, and KC lights.  I drove a big mercury station wagon to school sometimes.  Don’t laugh, it had a very beefy 390cu engine.

Good puzzle today, one of those themes that feels great when the lightbulb clicks on.  For me it was the Jet Li clue that got me thinking the right way.  

And always good when the clues all immediately make sense when you get them without crossings of ambiguous clues with obscure proper nouns.

I couldn’t make sense of the italicized clues, even though I knew (for example) that the “meditation chant” was OM. 

But when I got the SE corner filled in, the LI in PELICAN gave me the trick, and I was able to get the other theme answers pretty easily. 

Thanks for the fun, Mr. Wagner.

For some reason I didn't much enjoy the theme or the puzzle even though I got the theme early on. I guess I prefer long answers and stacks instead of a bunch of 5, 6 and 7 letter words. I never really thought about that before. It just feels choppy to me and not flowy. Just how my brain works I guess?

Cheers all and go Paolo!

This was so so much better than Wednesday’s  slog. 

INERTIA as slothfulness was a leap but given I’m recovering from yesterday I’ll let it pass 😀

Like others had bar instead of PAR for a while 

Thanks to the constructor/editors

Can someone please explain Adam's third paragraph? (Maybe Adam himself?) Not being a constructor, I didn't understand most of it.

As for solving the puzzle, the first theme answer was fortunately right up my alley. I got the answer from the crosses, then noticed the OM in it, and then figured out that the OM was surrounded by TOUCH, which is a sense. After that, knowing the theme really did help me out in a few places where I didn't know the downs right off the bat. 

I filled in RSSFEED immediately and wondered if I'd have to change it. Nope. That one stayed, but I think I fell for all the other traps that have been mentioned in the comments.

We have a guy here in Greenbelt who blows the SHOFAR every year for Rosh Hashana, so that one was a gimme despite my not being Jewish. (My husband's a non-religious Jew, so I'm pretty sure I didn't learn about it from him.)

🙋🏼‍♀️ hand up for entering kiNG before HONG. Like many others, I caught onto the trick with PELICAN. I knew Christopher REEVE was the Superman portrayer and once I had VAT, I k ew where REEVE went in the answer. Figured out OM as well, just had to get a couple of crosses to see where to place it. I mentally went through the senses and figured out TOUCH would work with OM. My final fill was the beginning S of SHOFARS. Really clever grid today, good enough that I didn’t miss my favorite Thursday rebus type. Thank you, Adam 😎

What is a crossword qualifier? Or how can you tell when there is one? 
Is it just the clue or is it after the comma (if there is one)?
I’m kind of new to crosswords. 
I wish NYT had an article that explains the terms they use and that basic understanding that they and the frequent crossword-doers seem to have

Just an interesting factoid about SHOFARS. 
In Hebrew the plural is shofarot (שופרות).

Wishing all who celebrate a Happy New Year שנה טובה!

Best,
Julia

I'm a British crossword doer usually, and the italicized clues reminded me of British cryptic clues - except they were missing the third part that these types of cryptic clues would have. So for fun I've had a go at adding it:

Meditation chant, in a sense, is excessive.
Tennis do-over, in a way takes inside and outside bets.
Superman portrayer, in so many words, comes occasionally.
Oopsie - it requires a passport or driver's licence, in a manner of speaking.
Action star Jet, in a nutshell, is often found at the beach.

Absolutely loved this puzzle! Some of the clues made me smile ( DIAPER was a funny one!) And I thought the theme very clever. I picked up on it pretty quick with PELICAN (which was my favourite of the lot!) I did confuse myself for a bit by putting REEVEs instead of REEVE and AUM (as it's often spelt in India) instead of OM, but eventually figured it out.
Well I, for one, instinctively entered HONG for 41A.  Go figure!

In German…

Ein = a
Eins = one

While “ein bier, bitte” and “eins bier, bitte”  are both correct and will get you a single beer, ein, zwei, drei, vier, funf is never correct (a, 2,3,4,5).
I loved this puzzle! You gave me that wonderful “aha” moment that is the best part of a Thursday!
Smart cluing, fun trick.

I loved this puzzle.  I had nothing in the top half and my first entry was king. Luckily the N and G were correct giving me two downs, which in turn opened up the SE corner and let me see that I need HONG instead.  Once I got PELICAN I saw the trick with the themers and I was able to work my way around the puzzle in a clockwise spiral from the SE and ending in the middle.

Clever and fresh, this puzzle got my day off to a good start.

An RSSFEED is something a site provides; the clue as written refers more accurately to software a person might use to aggregate feeds from multiple sites to create a “customizable all-in-one internet digest.” (Google Reader was one such tool before its demise.)

Which is to say: the clue is wrong.

Once again, we paper solvers have been thrown under the bus because of the omission of the italicized clues in the .pdf version. I do believe they were necessary to understanding the theme answers. Without them, it wasn't possible to discern just which ones they were. I finished almost all of the puzzle, with too many answers filled in thanks to the crosses  but not making sense, but couldn't get a couple of them. Not a happy camper.

Clever crossword.

CUZ/HUE were the hardest, I would say 'cos', and know nothing about graphic design.

I didn't know Jet Li so I got that with the crossers, and got lots of other unfamiliar terms the same way - like TRANSAM, SDSU, LARS. Looked up the lizard.

Overall, clever!
Hand up here. I tried King for Kong…..

Crossword superstar Paolo Pasco Jeopardy watch, day six ...

Victory once again, and impressive, as Paolo didn't land on a single Daily Double.  He won by betting big on the Final Jeopardy clue, which was "In April 2025 the Empire State Building was lit up green to celebrate the 100th anniversary of this novel’s publication" -- (answer in reply).

His winnings now total $162,117.
Enjoyed reading the constructor notes. When I got to the word “chonkiness” I was reminded of my daughter’s dismay at the whole grape tomatoes in her salad: “C’mon Mom, I need forkiness!”
Loooooooved.

I don't usually watch sports, but last weekend I was hanging out with two friends who were watching the Brewers game and switching over the the Lions/Bears game during commercials. I was APPALLED at the number of ads for sports betting. They even inserted them into the baseball game in little windows off to the side. Then on Sunday night I watched the Crawford/Canelo fight. Nothing but ads, ads, ads, all for sports betting. I would just as soon see ads for heroin, but I guess I'd better learn more about sports betting, judging from today.
Wonderful puzzle, with truly excellent clueing throughout, not to mention the clever theme.  Bravo!

38:42, 16:43 better than average. I was sure it was OMELETTE (spelt in a way) before fixing it to ROULETTE.  Cross-guessed HINNY and LACERTA. GIDEON and SHOFARS just seemed right from some corner of the memory even though I had no idea who and what they were. I think I encountered the latter in a clue in a recent archive solve. 

What a mind it takes to discover the theme word relationships and puns. My puns tend to be so rough and forced in comparison. Wonderful skill and requires such an immersion into the world of words. Amazing!
I finished without any hints and without understanding the theme. Tough Thursday puzzle for me.
What a splendid Thursday puzzle. I’m so impressed with folks who can solve a UK-style cryptic crossword. I needed all the crosses to get these.  Always a pleasure, Alex Wagner!

Took me a good long time to finally catch on to the trick, and only got it with a bunch of down crosses. That's all on me. This was a really clever way to be puzzling. Really odd puzzle find today. I was really puzzled by it but finally caught on. Anyway - a Thursday from June 7, 2018 by Bruce Haight. Sort of a description.... The answer to 33 down is: BUBBLESUP And then all the other theme answers are down answers that reference that. And the clue for every one of those answers is: "Carbonated beverage, spelled as 33 down might suggest." And some of those answers: OOLEMNSDA OOCHAMPAGNECLER OOJLTCLA OOCKEZER Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/7/2018&g=7&d=D ....

First pass through….oh dear, this is going to take a while. 
Second pass, okay getting there….
Figured out PE-LI-CAN and smooth sailing from there! NW corner was a little troublesome, but with help from crosses filled in quite nicely. 
Enjoyable Thursday - cross wording is my antidote to doomscrolling so I love a challenging puzzle (last Saturday was a whopper 😅)!

Over eighteen minutes faster than my 
Thursday average. Delighted!

Lovely moment: I was stuck on the corner of _inny and _ue, thinking of all the letters that could go in that square.  I left it blank, went elsewhere.  While I was elsewhere, my brain tapped me on the shoulder and excitedly whispered “HINNY!”  

Lovely moment: About halfway through, after having placed in three theme answers, seeing the trick.  Oh, that was sweet!

Other lovely moments as well.  The numerous ahas at cracking oblique clues.  The inner LOL at the PELICAN clue/answer.  The déjà vu at 5D – [Gets away from] – the ELUDES or EVADES kealoa we saw less than a week ago.  

Not to mention the overall shine of sweet wordplay in theme and clues, and the rub my brain cherishes.

Adam has shown once again that he has impressive grid-building chops.  This 70-word, 26-black-square grid looks like a Friday or Saturday, and is so cleanly filled. The theme is tight, too.  

Bravo and thank you, Adam – what a splendid heap of lovely you brought today!

This one felt more like a hefty Wednesday puzzle than a fun/tricky Thursday to me. Saw the theme with PELICAN, which helped me resolve some of the other thematic entries. Didn't find the theme or the themers all that interesting. 

LACERTA was an unusual entry that I actually knew, unlike HINNY, which was new to me. "Slothfulness" for INERTIA will require some more pondering.

Solid puzzle that took me about twenty minutes, which is a bit under my Thursday average.

This should be in the thread started by Emlyn 6 hours ago, but two attempts have not shown up yet.  Trying this way because sometimes it works:

The answer is in the first paragraph of the column.  Qualifiers are words or phrases like "in a way" or "in a sense" that limit meaning.  It's not a crossword-specific term; you might say "In a way, you're right" when you mean that the other person isn't completely right, or is right somehow by accident.

In this crossword, these qualifiers serve as wordplay rather than their normal meaning; "in a sense" means that the rest of the clue ("Meditation chant", or OM) is literally found wrapped within a sense (TOUCH).

This is not something that happens with regularity in American-style crosswords, but is common in cryptic (British-style) ones.  The NYT runs cryptic puzzles as the second Sunday puzzle every eight weeks, in rotation with several other types of puzzle.  They're not available on the NYT Games site/app, but can be played (on non-mobile devices only) at xwordinfo.com (membership required).

Hope this helps!

I found this one notably hard due to those chonky corners and a few words I couldn't produce: HINNY, LACERTA, and SHOFARS. What was fun was that PELICAN did indeed reveal the trick, and then the theme answers served as anchors for the rest of the solve, presumably as intended. A drag for me was having HINNI for a while as I misspelled LYON and that equine hybrid wasn't providing any helpful advice. Also checked in with the KING [Kong] gang.

Absolutely loved the theme. Easy enough to be approachable, but with just enough subtlety to provide a bit of resistance (and thus a fun moment when cracking it).

Now, I did not love SHOFARS so much…but I got the “O” (my last square in the grid) via the theme, which is always satisfying.
I love to be tickled. This was great.

Got the gold star and the music, and then went to work on "what the heck is the theme?".  All I had figured out by the time I completed the puzzle was that the answer to the clue seemed to be embedded in some bigger word or phrase.  Finally the light came on and I realized how the rest of the clue worked.  An outstanding Thursday puzzle.  I haven't read the comments yet, but if I hear someone suggest that the constructor got more pleasure constructing this puzzle than the solver did solving it, then I say to that person that is totally on you, and you need to solve a lot longer before you make such statements.
Delightfully fun and challening Thursday!  I vote yes for more from Adam.

(Haven't read comments yet; apologies for any duplicates.)

[Boomers, in essence]

[EGOT winner Moreno, in a play on words]








COLD SORE

PURITAN

Hi Deb! I figured out the theme pretty quickly, after the first themer, but I did not soar through the fill at all. Struggled quite a bit. Here's one my favorite use of musical SLURS, at least in the Common Practice Era (and it's very pretty!): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gm432J23_yo&list=RDgm432J23_yo&start_radio=1 (esp. about 2:25.)

V surprised to get the gold star as my stuffed up head found it very tricky, in a good way.
Got the theme with PE-LI-CAN then had fun working out the rest. The rest of the fill was chewier; no clue on betting, sports related or otherwise, ditto the bible ref. I could only think of David, which clearly didn’t fit. I had Adam at 52A for ages. Chuckled when I finally hit on SELF.

A good Thursday overall.

Got the theme instantly (nutshell Gabe it away) but solving it was tough because the end result was a word or phrase that seemed to have no relevance itself to the puzzle, other than fukfillingnthe clue.

Would have been way better if the answers had a theme or relevance.

The rest was challenging. Some pretty obscure stuff and difficult crosses.

Probably easy if you could get half of the trivia.

The constellation answer did not even show up when I googled list of constellations. Talk about niche.
Solved without understanding, again.  Even after reading the notes.

Great puzzle, but I kind of wish they had all been nut-themed.

My personal nut hangups aside, I did really enjoy this puzzle. SHOFARS, CRANE GAME, and GIDEON are all great entries. I had trouble with OVER UNDER, since I don't gamble. I find it so much easier to just set piles of cash on fire.
“My gridding skills”, as if a computer didn’t do the fill for you 🤣🤣🤣

Really enjoyed this puzzle, especially for a Thursday. Got stuck on one letter. I had BAR as a 40A “goal to shoot for.” This gave me PRIZEBOTS as 21D “holdings of winnings.” 

I was fairly certain this was the letter tripping me up, but “I’ve never heard of a prize bot” isn’t really helpful when I’ve also never heard of a HINNY or a SHOFAR. 
And, in this day and age, a robot holding on to your money made sense, even if I’d never heard of it. 

Had to check puzzle, then just keep guessing letters until I landed on P. Alas.
A new kealoa: hongking.

Used my usual "whistle past the graveyard"* technique in this perfectly puzzling gem.  Nicely done. 

*"Something is happenin' here but I don't know what it is. . ."
great, really clever construction. I adore a puzzle that has a distinct epiphany.

Quite shocked by the positive reception to this one.

A stockpile of poor cluing and google-able fill made the north half impenetrable, and while the south half felt more doable, still some nasty naticks poked their heads up, grinding progress to a halt. Disappointing when constructors and the editorial team feel such construction is publishable.

The usual cheap Thursday tricks are present, unfortunately, and there was no clue or hint how to solve those. A reliance on the Wordplay column to explain your gimmick does not a strong crossword puzzle make, I fear. Once “revealed”, the puzzler is left with no discernible theme, direction, or connection upon which they can hope to figure out the rest of the puzzle. Again, how these get by editorial is beyond me, but my experience has shown many are asleep at the wheel with these things.

Chose to reveal the puzzle rather than bumble through it. Critics will say it’s a me problem, and hey, maybe so. I don’t feel the best this morning and my brain hasn’t quite woken up for crosswords. But I couldn’t find it in me to try today when faced with such an uninspiring slog of a puzzle, all things considered.

That was fun! 
Like others, I did suss out that the obvious parts of the answers to the italicized clues were in the middle of the answer, but not the whole theme until I went back and looked afterward. Great job!
Fortunately I knew SHOFARS (and Rosh Hashanah is almost upon us), otherwise I was going to play with "wiki---something" at 1A.
Oh yeah...I'm supposed to be working, and I'm out of excuses! Have a good day.

I vote yes to this clever puzzle. I caught on with ACCIDENT which enabled me to polish off the REEVE clue. I like it when a theme, once understood, can help the solve. I was a bit stuck at the beginning as I’m not familiar with the OTHELLO game and though I’ve heard of RSS FEED I really don’t know what it is. (Well, I do now) Figuring out the  OM “in a sense” answer really helped me solve that quadrant and confirm the EVADE/ELUDE conundrum. 
TIL HINNY. H my final entry.

Though puzzle! The theme was tricky for me and the NW corner was brutal. A lot of unconventional word uses and/or made up terms. INERTIA is the law of what is in motion will stay in motion AND what is at rest will stay at rest but I think most of us only think of the first part… PRIZEPOTS? Never heard that usage. AGEMATE? 

Another variety of bark: WOOF
Slower than my average but worth the effort. Fresh theme and some clever misdirects in the fill, too. Loved it!
Well, I hit my average time. At sea on the theme.
I entered Donkey Kong, thinking it’s a rebus puzzle
Got the theme. Needed the theme! Middle of the puzzle was the toughest bit for me. TIL the difference between a HINNY and a mule!

Loved it, naturally. Got the theme near the beginning with PELICAN, then the Superman clue made sense and the rest of the themers fell fairly quickly. Having attempted cryptic crosswords in the past helped here, even though I am terrible at them.

Messed myself up in the NW by initially having 'linens' for 20A, which led to 'oman' for 7D and made 8D impossible, but once I let go of that, the rest of the puzzle fell. It helped that I was familiar with horse hybrids. There's always been something a bit poignant to me about hinnies.

Dear IT,

Do you think maybe once I have solved the puzzle and I go back to look at it that you could stop asking me if I am "Ready to start solving?" (website) or stop congratulating me (phone app)? 

Sincerely,
Jim

P.S. Thanks for finally relaxing the filter on short comments.
Really enjoyed the theme, but some of the fill like PRIZEPOTS and AGEMATE was a bit... much. PRIZEPOTS crossing HINNY and PAR (which I had as bAR for a time) took me a while to suss out.

I must say, when Adam latches onto a theme, he GOES BIG.

Took me a while to give up TRITONS in favor of SHOFARS. I now have a mental picture of Joshua and his men blowing into conch shells at the battle of Jericho. Of course, I had to look up GIDEON, who had his 300 men blow horns, smash jars, and light torches to convince the Midianites that he had a much larger force. TIL why there's a jar and a flame on the cover of the Gideon Bible.

And then there's the story of EL CID, whose men propped up his corpse on his horse and sent him into battle, convincing the superstitious Moors that he had come back from the dead. So we're all about deception today.

Regarding 28 down — HUE is not a synonym for color; it’s one of three properties of color, along with saturation (or chroma) and value (or lightness).

Signed, a graphic designer
Superb! I loved the theme, it must have taken some work to find enough words to work that way. The in a nutshell one was the first I got and it had me chuckling.
Really enjoyed that one!  Fun
My favorite themes are the ones that can be sussed out mid-solve, and help me answer the remaining theme clues. This was a nice example of that. Just right for a Thursday.

We arrived back home just in time for this puzzle. We had spent a week in LYON, where any resident will tell you it’s the second largest city in France using some obscure metric. 

But, the big payoffs were two answers from previously unheard from housemates. Metal head son knew the drummer and #1 grandson chipped in with the chess answer. 

In our house, it takes a village.

I held on to ADAM for 52A for way too long even as I kept thinking "PLASTIC would he good for 37D" and "APCLASS is perfect for 39D!" When I finally let it go, the relief of seeing LAP was so, so sweet. Great puzzle!!
Took me a long time to discover that a horse and bunny do not in fact make a HUNNY or HONNY

Really fun puzzle once I clued into the theme after several crossings.

For the life of me, I got stuck on one letter at the end for the clue "Goal to shoot for". I kept thinking "bar" because I figured that people aim to shoot for a performance bar.

Several reviews of ALL my answers later, I only realized my folly once I focused on the "Holdings of Winnings" crossing which makes a lot more sense with the correct letter 😅
I had to look up “chonky” to be sure it’s a word.  My autocorrect doesn’t think so, but now I know.  Chonky puzzles are daunting to me, but I look forward to any more Mr. Wagner wants to gift us.

I had a hard time getting through this, and then I remembered that there was a theme!

That helped, as soon as I figured the first one out....

I guess I was on the constructor's wavelength today. Absolutely loved this one! One of my favorites. Clever theme (which I suspected with REEVE but confirmed with PELICAN), no junk fill, great misdirects. fillY before HINNY slowed me down. 
A superb, perfectly crunchy Thursday. 
I've already forgotten about yesterday's numbers! 😂
I did enjoy this one, though it almost made me go above my Thursday average solve time! Seemed like lots of new clues. And I love a good word-play theme!

I would qualify RSS FEED as a tricky clue, in fact very tricky. I could only solve it with the down words, and after I googled the definition I'm not sure I understand the concept totally. How many among you fellow solvers knew this term?

This one started out slow for me, but then the PELICAN made it fly! So fun.

Question: Why is a horse + a jenny not a henny? Or a jorse? (I wish it were a honkey.)

For me it was a slog to solve, but a lot of that is that I only figured out half the theme.   Meaning, I did get that the answer to the first half of the clue was inside the answer.... So I was able to come up with ID, OM, REEVE, etc.   But, I failed to realize that there was a second half;  in other words, I erroneously thought that over was supposed to figure out the middle of the answer and then one would have to come up with a solution by figuring out common words or sayings via the acrosses (for instance, for 58 across I had P-LICA- and I decided the only word that would fit would be Pelican, but I never thought about Li being wrapped inside Pecan, which was the trick of the whole puzzle).    Never figuring out that trick, and never doing any lookups on the Internet made this a slog for me, but that was my own fault for failing to see there were two parts to the trick and not just one.  I also for the longest time felt that my guess of LaCorta for 38D must be correct, which kept me from figuring out SOL- for the 52A.   I finally figured out SELF, and thus it was Lacerta.     Glad other's brains were able to figure out the whole truck and this have a much more enjoyable solve than I did.

This was an impressive challenge and most definitely not on my wavelength!  I needed some look-ups and help with “Tricky Clues” and letting the puzzle sit overnight, but at least I figured out the theme by myself.
Full of fun moments, not the least of which was changing King Kong to Hong Kong.

LARS was my first solve right out the gate. I saw Metallica live in Golden Gate Park in the before times. Best live show I've ever seen, but Parker and Stone got it right.

I made a somewhat educated guess on SDSU, and filled the southeast corner in pretty quickly. In the end, it was the poker references and INERTIA that had me stumped. I, for one, revere the humble sloths and their nice healthy speeds of slow, and had always thought of inertia in terms of high speed. TIL!

When alternate words fit and create a seemingly logical cross, you can get in a jam.

There are such things as "prizebots" and a "bar" is a reasonable goal to shoot for, whether it's high, or in the current moment, desperately low.
Clever theme! I smiled when I figured it out about halfway through my solve. (FWIW, I always do the down clues first, except on Mondays and Minis.)

I am absolutely shocked that I got this puzzle done on my first go-round. That is not to say that I finished it by myself...hardly! I had the help of all of my fellow commenters, and Deb, and Adam in his comments as well! But even so, I did most of it myself, and expected to find that, when I fit in that last letter, I would have spelled something wrong and would spend an hour trying to figure out what it was.

A very interesting, complicated, and fun puzzle for me, and just the right amount of tension for a Thursday. It took me the better part of my day, as I am going back and forth with Apple Support (this has been going on for two weeks now) as they try to solve The Mystery of the Disappearing Mailbox. We are at the supervisor/engineer level now, where they and then call me with yet another attempt that fails. "But we're getting there!" they tell me. "Uh huh" I answer. 

Stay tune.
Wow!  Great puzzle. I’m in awe of you and a bit of me since I did finally solve it fair and square. What a workout!  Thanks.

I solved the puzzle without cheating, but had to come here to understand the theme. 
It's like doing Connections: 90% of the time when only 4 words are left, I have no idea how they're connected.
Great puzzle, great theme, great fill, great fun.

This was a tricky one for me. For some reason I was under the impression that "Bonn" was a French city, so for a long time I had UNE for 29-across. 

I was also super befuddled by ACCIDENT until I saw that in contained ID, which got me thinking in terms of the theme.

Until another commenter pointed it out, I also didn't notice that the letters surrounding the nested words spelled out words of their own, corresponding to the latter half of the theme clues (e.g. ACCidENT - "accent" - "a manner of speaking) That's some next level thinking!

One more late puzzle find - another with a theme I've never, ever seen before. A Thursday from August 2, 2011 by Bruce F. Adams. Had a furrowed brow for quite a while until I finally figured out the trick. Theme clues and answers: "Chapeau holder, spelled out in detail?" TECIRCUMFLEXTE "Targets of some beatings, spelled out in detail?" PINTILDEATAS "1930's-40's tyrant, spelled out in detail?" FUUMLAUTHRER "Illusions, spelled out in detail?" FACCEDILLAADES And there was no 'reveal.' Here's the link to that one: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/2/2001&g=20&d=A ...

This one made me squirm and sweat a bit. Like others, I found the SE quadrant to be the easiest port of entry, and PELICAN gave me the formula to understand the theme. I made a LOT of educated guesses and uneducated hunches today, but most of them paid off. Nice to know that Rex Parker found it Challenging, cuz I did, too.

This was surprisingly a quick solve for me. I really dug today's trick. I did not have fun with the rest of the puzzle.

When the last letter went in and the gold star popped up I scared my daughter with my whoop of surprise! I worked on it, on and off, all day, well and a bit last night. Geez, what a workout! 

I do love challenging, and challenging this was. I got the trick early on but so many of the clues just had me stymied. From somewhere, I don't know where, EL CID eventually surfaced,  and slowly, the more I filled in, the easier it got. A lot of guessing and trial and error though, but, got there in the end. 

Woo hoo!
I looooved the clueing and fill today. It's funny how you feel as if you get to know a constructor from their puzzle. Have Adam back please.

And so here I am,
trudging in with a weary heart,
Late in the game with a star in the West.
Impaled, squirming in shame
Hoisted by that gnarled trumpet,
That gleaming shofar.

The Zen blindly cried out in protest.
The neophyte mind searched -
Mu! Mu! I must have MU
What is MU?
Blinded, unwilling to give up on,

TOu MU CH

Then calm, the wave breaks, the walls settle . . .

OM

Anagram with the hint of an anagram:
Senator arranged crime (7) = TREASON

Deity’s pet comes back (3) = GOD

These are easy examples to get you into the way of it.

You may know OTHELLO as Reversi. One player plays white, the other black. One has to flank opposing pieces to play, which flips the opposing pieces to your color. Repeat until grid is filled or no possible moves for one player. Person with most pieces of their color on the board at the end wins.

@Beth in Greenbelt

I’ll try - it’s all due to the rules of a) minimum 3 letters answers; b) grid symmetry; and c) theme answer symmetry:

1) There are 5 theme answers.  Typically theme answers have to be in symmetrical parts of the grid - TOOMUCH and PELICAN (6); ROULETTE and ACCIDENT (7), and then the 5th has to go in the middle row because there is no counterpart.  As it is 9 letters, the only way to make this fit is in the middle, leading to three blocks on either side.  

Then the fact that it is his preference to have PELICAN(7) in row 13 means that there have to be three vertical blocks in that row.  If this were a 6 letters answer instead, the bottom three blocks would have gone in row 9 instead of 8, and the top in row 7, which would have allowed for vertical blocks in row 4 or 5 on the bottom and 10 or 11 on top, creating shorter answers than the 7 stacks on each side.

He could have chosen two blocks in row 12 on the top and four on the bottom to create eight more 3-letter across answers instead, but that would have been suboptimal for obvious reasons.

@Emlyn
There’s an excellent book by Amy Reynaldo called, “How to Conquer the New York Times Crossword Puzzle” that gives you a list of the 100 must-know words, word banks in various genres of knowledge, tips on how to conquer each day of the week, and over 60 practice puzzles. It helped me a ton when I was a new daily solver!

@Nora

It's great to provide that article to those who are new to solving, but it does not explain "qualifier." Neither your nor eatnik have actually answered Emlyn's question.

@Emlyn

The answer is in the first paragraph of the column.  Qualifiers are words or phrases like "in a way" or "in a sense" that limit meaning.  It's not a crossword-specific term; you might say "In a way, you're right" when you mean that the other person isn't completely right, or is right somehow by accident.

In this crossword, these qualifiers serve as wordplay rather than their normal meaning; "in a sense" means that the rest of the clue ("Meditation chant", or OM) is literally found wrapped within a sense (TOUCH).

This is not something that happens with regularity in American-style crosswords, but is common in cryptic (British-style) ones.  The NYT runs cryptic puzzles as the second Sunday puzzle every eight weeks, in rotation with several other types of puzzle.  They're not available on the NYT Games site/app, but can be played (on non-mobile devices only) at xwordinfo.com (membership required).

Hope this helps!

@eatnik

I was just going to say this is about the closest we get to the British-style cryptic, which I never have been able to get my head around. This is the first I've learned that there are typically three elements to these types of clues. That might help me crack the code. In your examples, it is clear. Thanks!

@Teresa

 There are normally two elements in a cryptic clue: 

1. The overall meaning

2. A witty hint that points you to the right answer, without any link to the meaning; e.g. an anagram. Very often this will not give you the whole answer in one go. Instead, it will provide several references to individual syllables or letters, and once you have sussed them all out, you put them together. (It helps enormously to be familiar with the regular style of that crossword, so practice makes perfect.)

So there are two chances to get the answer. Either you spot the meaning, and confirm it with the cryptic elements, or you add up the cryptic ingredients and get the answer with a shout, or groan, of “aha!!”. 

The difficulty, usually, is parsing the clue, to work out which bit is the cryptic chunk and which bit is the meaning.

@Andrzej
There are a lot of conventions with cryptic crosswords, ways of doing things, and cultural references just as with the NYT one. 

Years ago ( maybe not now) when I did cryptics, referring to a sailor would mean using AB (Able Seaman) or 'tar' (Jack Tar is a historical term for a sailor). 

Clue:
Savour impertinence from sailors? (6,5)

[ wordplay: synonym for ‘sailor’ twice (because ‘sailors’) + synonym for ‘impertinence’ ]
[ TAR + TAR + SAUCE ]
[ definition: savour (as a noun, not a verb) ]

=  TARTAR SAUCE.

@Petrol Some cryptic clues do not include the hint as to what they are, for example, when the answer is a hidden word spelled out in the clue. But these clues are usually pretty long and very strange or obscure, so experienced solvers will look for a hidden word.

The cryptic forumula was described to me once as "algebraic". Once you solve for the definition clues and the format/hint words, there should only be minor stopwords such as "the" left.

Except that sometimes the  "the" is part of the clue.

A
N
S
W
E
R

@Andrzej
In fact, Paolo will be back later this season, even after his winning streak ends: all those who win 5 or more games come back for a Tournament of Champions. Really BIG winners tend to be invited back multiple times, in successive years. That is what happened to Ken Jennings (referred to above for his 74-game streak). He racked up millions over the years. When the longtime and widely beloved host, Alex Trebek, died, Jennings accepted the job as host... of course he can no longer compete in tournaments!

@D

Not sure what you mean when you say there was no clue or hint on how to solve the themers—the italics let you know there’s a trick there and the clues were pretty self explanatory. I, and I’m sure many others, were able to figure it out without reading the wordplay column.

@D

I can't tell from your comment whether you actually understood the structure of the theme clues. Thursdays often borrow from all kinds of puzzle concepts; today the clues used a structure common in cryptic crosswords. Deb described the specifics. Forgive me if I'm about to explain something you already know or if the general structure has been discussed below. I have to work now. 

In cryptic crosswords, clues are typically in two parts, with a straightforward clue and then a trick. Those parts here were clearly denoted by the comma. The part before the comma was straightforward, the part after the comma, "in ______" was a clue that the word from the first half of the clue appeared inside the word referred to in the blank.

I did not get the bit about modifiers until reading the Wordplay column, but I did not need that for the solve.

@D

“The usual cheap Thursday tricks are present, unfortunately, and there was no clue or hint how to solve those. A reliance on the Wordplay column to explain your gimmick does not a strong crossword puzzle make, I fear.”

The media solve time for users of xwstats is currently 16:30, which is about what I would have guessed based on my own experience — and assuredly, the great majority of those users did not need to consult the wordplay column to grok the theme. Personally, I enjoyed the theme very much, though I’d say it was a bit on the gentle/easy side for a Thursday gimmick.

Sounds like this puzzle was simply beyond your current solving abilities. There’s no shame whatsoever in that. Why not just acknowledge it?

@D

I understand that you didn’t like it and appreciate your taking time to explain the reasons why. I think the bridge too far is suggesting that the constructor shouldn’t have submitted it or the editors publish it. Whatever your subjective feeling personally, objectively it should be clear to you (if you read the other comments) that lots of people enjoyed it a lot, and thus it was a worthy puzzle to be published. Say your peace about your own opinions and then leave it at that.

@D - Yeah, it's a "you" problem. I never rely on or even read the Wordplay column prior to solving, this puzzle included (which I solved in well below my average Thursday time FWIW).

Maybe refrain from commenting on days when you "don't feel the best", in the future?

@D 
As Taylor Swift sings in Anti-Hero...

@Mr Ochie
Every theme clue consists of what seems to be a limiting phrase ("a sense") but is in fact an element of the answer (TOUCH). Take that and put a word derived from the other piece of the clue (OM) /in/ it. Et voila! TO(OM)UCH. 

Nothing in the clue defines the whole answer but the bricks used to build it are each defined. You're the builder.

In true cryptic crosswords  the clue would also have included an element that solved to the entire answer (e.g., "oversupply")

@Bill In hexadecimal colour codes, two digits represent red, two green and two blue.

HSL works as a shorthand for hue, saturation and lightness but they use integers 0-100. 

Eric is right, you can’t use a hex code to denote a hue. 

Hope that helps! Signed, another graphic designer.
